comments.author: Chris Blackmore (The Walrus)

comments.text:
+Chris Blackmore I have a brother who once thought as you do; I think I 
know why. There is a common misunderstanding about the way gyroscopes, and 
gyroscopic precession, work. The key is "torsion". This refers to axial 
force, not linear force.

The videos and images I see online which describe gyroscopic precession all 
use arrows to refer to angles re-directions of force. It's the arrows that 
are misleading. The force is not actually applied "in a direction", but 
"around an axis". So, when you hold up one side of a spinning gyro, the 
force you need to consider shouldn't be represented as a linear arrow 
(acting "down" against the other side). even though that is happening.

The way it should be represented is as an arrow that is curved around the 
axial center of the gyroscope. When gravity pulls one side of it down, it 
applies a torsional force around the center of the gyro. The redirection 
that occurs as a result of gyroscopic precession isn't a 90 degree spatial 
vector, but a 90 degree torsional redirection around the axis of the 
gyroscope. Therefore, the "twist" that gravity is trying to make is 
redirected around the axis of the gyro, not through the space it occupies.
comments.author: Phil Snelgrove

2 types of Gravity are cancelling the other out.

comments.text:
+Michael Groesbeck Again, that is a philosophical position and physicists 
have very little patience with, or need for, philosophy. The entire history 
of physics shows that 'exploration' (in the sense that a biologist or 
botanist or even an astronomer uses it) played very little part. Physics is 
much closer to the examination of 'found objects' (which is how Newton saw 
it, by the way) and the resolution of small anomalies and paradoxes was the 
driving force. The anomaly in the precession of the perihelion of Mercury 
led to relativity and the so-called ultraviolet catastrophe led to quantum 
mechanics. There has been no major advance in physics for nearly 100 years, 
precisely because physicists are content that their present theories are 
adequate. There are still searches for ways of coupling electromagnetism to 
gravity and relativity to quantum mechanics but I think that those quests 
are 'begging the question' (in the formal-logic sense, not the incorrect 
everyday sense).

comments.text:
+Alan Crook You should not believe 'popular media' versions of history. The 
linear (and rotary) induction motors were patented by Wheatstone in about 
1860. In fact, just after Laithwaite had finished a lecture on 'his' 
invention, a mischievous colleague opened a cupboard in the old 
lecture-room and revealed Wheatstone's own prototype motor! And yes, 
Wheatstone invented the motor before there was any way of powering it. That 
is true genius.
comments.author: MrAaronvee

comments.text:
+MrAaronvee One of his crackpot ideas was the linear induction motor that 
the Japanese use to power speed  record breaking trains.
comments.author: Alan Crook

comments.text:
+John James Nope: I would still go with 'liar'. I have made a detailed 
study of Laithwaite's 'career', and this was far from being an isolated 
incident. He backed all sorts of crackpot ideas, persistently derided 
physicists, and concealed the sources of his own 'discoveries'. He must 
have known very well that this demonstration was nearly 200 years old. I 
consider Laithwaite to have been the worst case, of a crackpot infiltrating 
the scientific establishment, since Trofim Lysenko. And I shall be saying 
that in a forthcoming book.

comments.text:
+Alex Kostko That's actually a common misconception about how aircraft 
wings work. Aircraft wings work by deflecting air downwards, both below 
with positive pressure and above with less than background pressure.

If there is no net change in momentum of the background air, then there is 
no force upward on the wing. But because there is a net change in momentum 
downward of the air, there is a force on the wing.

succession, so I imagine that my frustration spilled over onto yours. The 
fact remains that gyroscopes cannot propel or levitate. The basic point is 
that the plane obeys Newton's Third Law, the gyroscope in the vid above 
obeys it, but no arrangement of gyroscopes can fail to obey it and so 
 therefore cannot levitate. On the other hand, the rotating millstones in 
an old-fashioned windmill actually exert a downwards force which is greater 
than their static weight. The dictionary definition of umpteenth is

to keep object still and stable...to overcome torque effects. When the 
torque effects are removed objects "appear" less heavy. Even though of 
course they stay the same weight.
comments.author: Quentin David

comments.text:
+Quentin David Well the main point is how difficult it is to make people 
understand what is really going on. If you want another challenge: there is 
a vid somewhere showing a Shaolin monk supposedly resisting (one with each 
arm) the opposed pull of two bullocks. Just try to convince the layman that 
he is resisting only one bullock. It is near-impossible! What on Earth do 
school physics teachers do all day?
comments.author: David Fisher

comments.text:
Thinking about it a bit more -- I would say the Gyroscope effect ..removing 
all the torque is responsible for 99 percent for the fact that it seems 
easier to hold.

twisting of the body causing other muscles to be used may be 1 percent.
comments.author: Quentin David

comments.text:
+Quentin David If the precession is 'hurried' (i.e. if one twists faster 
than is necessary to keep up with it) the top will suddenly rise higher and 
look as if it is really taking off. This phenomenon has been known for some 
200 years and is sometimes called the 'Kelvin Effect'.
comments.author: David Fisher

comments.text:
I know what you are saying--- the Gyroscope effect is removing the torque 
so it is much easier to hold...and that is probably making it 90 percent 
easier to hold...but If you watch video you notice his body is twisting a 
bit and that will be redisributing some of the energy into other muscles 
(not just upper arm)..

people that have done the experiment say it feels much lighter ... I was 
trying to think of reasons for that ...and it all might not just be 
reduction in torque effect.

comments.text:
+Intellectual Farce You said, "...weight of a spaceship would be the 
same..." WRONG. That's NOT what I said. ANY object's WEIGHT is going to be 
different depending on the gravity field it's in. A space ship "floating" 
in space is going to have ZERO WEIGHT. It's MASS will remain unchanged. You 
keep confusing the two. The spinning gyro will always have the same mass 
and the same weight on Earth. On the Moon the weight will be lighter, but

comments.text:
+sashank reddy All of the forces associated with gyroscopes are couples. 
Angular and linear momentum are separately conserved. These two facts alone 
rule out any sort of propulsive or levitational effect. But that conclusion 
applies only to Newtonian mechanics. General relativity theory offers the 
possibility of a levitational effect, but it is truly minute: the 
peripheral velocity of the wheel would have to be about Mach 10000 in order 
to give a measurable effect.
